para.sentence: The main functions treated in this chapter are the basic hypergeometric (or q -hypergeometric) function {{}_{r}\phi_{s}}\left(a_{1},a_{2},\dots,a_{r};b_{1},b_{2},\dots,b_{s};q,z\right) , the bilateral basic hypergeometric (or bilateral q -hypergeometric) function {{}_{r}\psi_{s}}\left(a_{1},a_{2},\dots,a_{r};b_{1},b_{2},\dots,b_{s};q,z\right) , and the q -analogs of the Appell functions \Phi^{(1)}\left(a;b,b^{\prime};c;q;x,y\right) , \Phi^{(2)}\left(a;b,b^{\prime};c,c^{\prime};q;x,y\right) , \Phi^{(3)}\left(a,a^{\prime};b,b^{\prime};c;q;x,y\right) , and \Phi^{(4)}\left(a,b;c,c^{\prime};q;x,y\right).

Another function notation used is the “idem” function: f(\chi_{1};\chi_{2},\dots,\chi_{n})+\mathrm{idem}\left(\chi_{1};\chi_{2},\dots ,\chi_{n}\right)=\sum_{j=1}^{n}f(\chi_{j};\chi_{1},\chi_{2},\dots,\chi_{j-1}, \chi_{j+1},\dots,\chi_{n}).
A slightly different notation is that in ( ) and ( ) ; see §LABEL:sec:QH.4(i).
( ) uses F(a,b;t:q) for a particular specialization of a {{}_{2}\phi_{1}} function.
In the limit as q\to 1 , (LABEL:eq:QH.2.35) reduces to the standard binomial theorem \sum_{j=0}^{n}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{n}{j}(-z)^{j}=(1-z)^{n}.
When a=q^{m+1} , where m is a nonnegative integer, (LABEL:eq:QH.2.37) reduces to the q -binomial series \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\genfrac{[}{]}{0.0pt}{}{n+m}{n}_{q}z^{n}=\frac{1}{\left(z;q \right)_{m+1}}.
When n\to\infty in (LABEL:eq:QH.2.35), and when m\to\infty in (LABEL:eq:QH.2.38), the results become convergent infinite series and infiniteproducts (see (LABEL:eq:QH.5.4) and (LABEL:eq:QH.5.3)).
The q -derivatives of f(z) are defined by \mathcal{D}_{q}f(z)=\begin{cases}\dfrac{f(z)-f(zq)}{(1-q)z},&z\neq 0,\\ f^{\prime}(0),&z=0,\end{cases} and
When q\to 1 the q -derivatives converge to the corresponding ordinary derivatives.

If f(x) is continuous at x=0 , then \int_{0}^{1}f(x){\mathrm{d}}_{q}x=(1-q)\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}f(q^{j})q^{j}, and more generally, \int_{0}^{a}f(x){\mathrm{d}}_{q}x=a(1-q)\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}f(aq^{j})q^{j}.
If f(x) is continuous on [0,a] , then \lim_{q\to 1-}\int_{0}^{a}f(x){\mathrm{d}}_{q}x=\int_{0}^{a}f(x)\mathrm{d}x.
These identities are the first in a large collection of similar results.

subsection.title: Bernoulli Polynomials; Euler and Stirling Numbers

para.sentence: The \beta_{n}\left(x,q\right) are, in fact, rational functions of q , and not necessarily polynomials.
The A_{m,s}\left(q\right) are always polynomials in q , and the a_{m,s}\left(q\right) are polynomials in q for 0\leq s\leq m.
Here and elsewhere it is assumed that the b_{j} do not take any of the values q^{-n}.
The infinite series converges for all z when s>r , and for |z|<1 when s=r.
For the function on the right-hand side see §LABEL:sec:GH.DF.GHS.
It is slightly at variance with the notation in ( ) and ( ) .
In these references the factor \left((-1)^{n}q^{\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{n}{2}}\right)^{s-r } is not included in the sum.
In practice this discrepancy does not usually cause serious problems because the case most often considered is r=s.
Here and elsewhere the b_{j} must not take any of the values q^{-n} , and the a_{j} must not take any of the values q^{n+1}.
The infinite series converge when s\geq r provided that |(b_{1}\cdots b_{s})/(a_{1}\cdots a_{r}z)|<1 and also, in the case s=r , |z|<1.

The following definitions apply when |x|<1 and |y|<1 : \Phi^{(1)}\left(a;b,b^{\prime};c;q;x,y\right)=\sum_{m,n\geq 0}\frac{\left(a;q \right)_{m+n}\left(b;q\right)_{m}\left(b^{\prime};q\right)_{n}x^{m}y^{n}}{ \left(q;q\right)_{m}\left(q;q\right)_{n}\left(c;q\right)_{m+n}}, , \Phi^{(2)}\left(a;b,b^{\prime};c,c^{\prime};q;x,y\right)=\sum_{m,n\geq 0}\frac {\left(a;q\right)_{m+n}\left(b;q\right)_{m}\left(b^{\prime};q\right)_{n}x^{m}y ^{n}}{\left(q;q\right)_{m}\left(q;q\right)_{n}\left(c;q\right)_{m}\left(c^{ \prime};q\right)_{n}}, , \Phi^{(3)}\left(a,a^{\prime};b,b^{\prime};c;q;x,y\right)=\sum_{m,n\geq 0}\frac {\left(a,b;q\right)_{m}\left(a^{\prime},b^{\prime};q\right)_{n}x^{m}y^{n}}{ \left(q;q\right)_{m}\left(q;q\right)_{n}\left(c;q\right)_{m+n}}, , \Phi^{(4)}\left(a,b;c,c^{\prime};q;x,y\right)=\sum_{m,n\geq 0}\frac{\left(a,b; q\right)_{m+n}x^{m}y^{n}}{\left(q,c;q\right)_{m}\left(q,c^{\prime};q\right)_{n }}.
The series (LABEL:eq:QH.4.1) is said to be balanced orSaalschützian when it terminates, r=s , z=q , and qa_{0}a_{1}\cdots a_{s}=b_{1}b_{2}\cdots b_{s}.
The series (LABEL:eq:QH.4.1) is said to be k-balanced when r=s and q^{k}a_{0}a_{1}\cdots a_{s}=b_{1}b_{2}\cdots b_{s}.
The series (LABEL:eq:QH.4.1) is said to be well-poised when r=s and a_{0}q=a_{1}b_{1}=a_{2}b_{2}=\dots=a_{s}b_{s}.
The series (LABEL:eq:QH.4.1) is said to be very-well-poised when r=s , (LABEL:eq:QH.4.11) is satisfied, and b_{1}=-b_{2}=\sqrt{a_{0}}.
The series (LABEL:eq:QH.4.1) is said to be nearly-poised when r=s and a_{0}q=a_{1}b_{1}=a_{2}b_{2}=\dots=a_{s-1}b_{s-1}.
This reverses the order of summation in (LABEL:eq:QH.6.2):

paragraph.title: Nonterminating Form of the q-Vandermonde Sum

para.sentence: For a similar result for q -confluent hypergeometric functions see ( ) .

{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c/q};q,z\right)-{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b \atop c};q,z\right)=cz\frac{(1-a)(1-b)}{(q-c)(1-c)}{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq, bq\atop cq};q,z\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,b\atop c};q,z\right)-{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c };q,z\right)=az\frac{1-b}{1-c}{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,bq\atop cq};q,z\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,b\atop cq};q,z\right)-{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b \atop c};q,z\right)=az\frac{(1-b)(1-(c/a))}{(1-c)(1-cq)}{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left( {aq,bq\atop cq^{2}};q,z\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,b/q\atop c};q,z\right)-{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b \atop c};q,z\right)=az\frac{(1-b/(aq))}{1-c}{{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,b\atop cq };q,z\right), b(1-a){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,b\atop c};q,z\right)-a(1-b){{}_{2}\phi_{1}} \left({a,bq\atop c};q,z\right)=(b-a){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c};q,z \right), , a\left(1-\frac{b}{c}\right){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b/q\atop c};q,z\right)-b \left(1-\frac{a}{c}\right){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a/q,b\atop c};q,z\right)=(a-b )\left(1-\frac{abz}{cq}\right){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c};q,z\right), q\left(1-\frac{a}{c}\right){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a/q,b\atop c};q,z\right)+(1- a)\left(1-\frac{abz}{c}\right){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({aq,b\atop c};q,z\right)= \left(1+q-a-\frac{aq}{c}+\frac{a^{2}z}{c}-\frac{abz}{c}\right){{}_{2}\phi_{1}} \left({a,b\atop c};q,z\right), (1-c)(q-c)(abz-c){{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c/q};q,z\right)+z(c-a)(c-b){{ }_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop cq};q,z\right)=(c-1)(c(q-c)+z(ca+cb-ab-abq)){{}_ {2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c};q,z\right).
(LABEL:eq:QH.6.27)reduces to the hypergeometric equation (LABEL:eq:HY.DE.DE) with the substitutions a\to q^{a} , b\to q^{b} , c\to q^{c} , followed by \lim_{q\to 1-}.

, {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c};q,z\right)=\left(\frac{-1}{2\pi i}\right) \frac{\left(a,b;q\right)_{\infty}}{\left(q,c;q\right)_{\infty}}\int_{-i\infty} ^{i\infty}\frac{\left(q^{1+\zeta},cq^{\zeta};q\right)_{\infty}}{\left(aq^{ \zeta},bq^{\zeta};q\right)_{\infty}}\frac{\pi(-z)^{\zeta}}{\sin\left(\pi\zeta \right)}\mathrm{d}\zeta, where |z|<1 , |\operatorname{ph}\left(-z\right)|<\pi , and the contour of integration separates the poles of \left(q^{1+\zeta},cq^{\zeta};q\right)_{\infty}/\sin\left(\pi\zeta\right) from those of 1/\left(aq^{\zeta},bq^{\zeta};q\right)_{\infty} , and the infimum of the distances of the poles from the contour is positive.
For continued-fraction representations of the {{}_{2}\phi_{1}} function, see ( , pp. 395–399) .

paragraph.title: Nonterminating Form of the q-Saalschütz Sum
F. H. Jackson’s Terminating q-Analog of Dixon’s Sum

para.sentence: For continued-fraction representations of a ratio of {{}_{3}\phi_{2}} functions, see ( , pp. 399–400) .

{{}_{8}\phi_{7}}\left({\lambda,q\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}},-q\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}, a,b,c,-c,\lambda q/c^{2}\atop\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}},-\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}, \lambda q/a,\lambda q/b,\lambda q/c,-\lambda q/c,c^{2}};q,-\frac{\lambda q}{ab }\right)=\frac{\left(\lambda q,c^{2}/\lambda;q\right)_{\infty}\left(aq,bq,c^{2 }q/a,c^{2}q/b;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}{\left(\lambda q/a,\lambda q/b;q\right)_{ \infty}\left(q,abq,c^{2}q,c^{2}q/(ab);q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}, where \lambda=-c(ab/q)^{\frac{1}{2}}.

paragraph.title: F. H. Jackson’s q-Analog of Dougall’s {{}_{7}F_{6}}\left(1\right) Sum

para.sentence: {{}_{6}\phi_{5}}\left({a,qa^{\frac{1}{2}},-qa^{\frac{1}{2}},b,c,d\atop a^{ \frac{1}{2}},-a^{\frac{1}{2}},aq/b,aq/c,aq/d};q,\frac{aq}{bcd}\right)=\frac{ \left(aq,aq/(bc),aq/(bd),aq/(cd);q\right)_{\infty}}{\left(aq/b,aq/c,aq/d,aq/( bcd);q\right)_{\infty}}, and when d=q^{-n} , {{}_{6}\phi_{5}}\left({a,qa^{\frac{1}{2}},-qa^{\frac{1}{2}},b,c,q^{-n}\atop a^ {\frac{1}{2}},-a^{\frac{1}{2}},aq/b,aq/c,aq^{n+1}};q,\frac{aq^{n+1}}{bc}\right )=\frac{\left(aq,aq/(bc);q\right)_{n}}{\left(aq/b,aq/c;q\right)_{n}}.

paragraph.title: Bailey’s Nonterminating Extension of Jackson’s {{}_{8}\phi_{7}} Sum
Gasper–Rahman q-Analogs of the Karlsson–Minton Sums

para.sentence: {{}_{r+2}\phi_{r+1}}\left({a,b,b_{1}q^{m_{1}},\dots,b_{r}q^{m_{r}}\atop bq,b_{ 1},\dots,b_{r}};q,a^{-1}q^{1-(m_{1}+\cdots+m_{r})}\right)=\frac{\left(q,bq/a;q \right)_{\infty}\left(b_{1}/b;q\right)_{m_{1}}\cdots\left(b_{r}/b;q\right)_{m_ {r}}}{\left(bq,q/a;q\right)_{\infty}\left(b_{1};q\right)_{m_{1}}\cdots\left(b_ {r};q\right)_{m_{r}}}b^{m_{1}+\cdots+m_{r}}, and {{}_{r+1}\phi_{r}}\left({a,b_{1}q^{m_{1}},\dots,b_{r}q^{m_{r}}\atop b_{1}, \dots,b_{r}};q,a^{-1}q^{1-(m_{1}+\cdots+m_{r})}\right)=0, where m_{1},m_{2},\dots,m_{r} are arbitrary nonnegative integers.

paragraph.title: Gasper’s Extensions of Gosper’s Bibasic Sum

para.sentence: {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c};q,z\right)=\frac{\left(za;q\right)_{\infty} }{\left(z;q\right)_{\infty}}{{}_{2}\phi_{2}}\left({a,c/b\atop c,az};q,bz\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({q^{-n},b\atop c};q,z\right)=\frac{\left(c/b;q\right)_{n }}{\left(c;q\right)_{n}}b^{n}{{}_{3}\phi_{1}}\left({q^{-n},b,q/z\atop bq^{1-n} /c};q,z/c\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({a,b\atop c};q,z\right)=\frac{\left(abz/c;q\right)_{ \infty}}{\left(bz/c;q\right)_{\infty}}{{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({a,c/b,0\atop c,cq /bz};q,q\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({q^{-n},b\atop c};q,z\right)=\frac{\left(c/b;q\right)_{n }}{\left(c;q\right)_{n}}\left(\frac{bz}{q}\right)^{n}{{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^ {-n},q/z,q^{1-n}/c\atop bq^{1-n}/c,0};q,q\right), , {{}_{2}\phi_{1}}\left({q^{-n},b\atop c};q,z\right)=\frac{\left(c/b;q\right)_{n }}{\left(c;q\right)_{n}}{{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^{-n},b,bzq^{-n}/c\atop bq^{1- n}/c,0};q,q\right).

{{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({a,b,c\atop d,e};q,de/(abc)\right)=\frac{\left(e/a,de/( bc);q\right)_{\infty}}{\left(e,de/(abc);q\right)_{\infty}}{{}_{3}\phi_{2}} \left({a,d/b,d/c\atop d,de/(bc)};q,e/a\right), , {{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({a,b,c\atop d,e};q,de/(abc)\right)=\frac{\left(b,de/(ab) ,de/(bc);q\right)_{\infty}}{\left(d,e,de/(abc);q\right)_{\infty}}\*{{}_{3}\phi _{2}}\left({d/b,e/b,de/(abc)\atop de/(ab),de/(bc)};q,b\right), , {{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^{-n},b,c\atop d,e};q,q\right)=\frac{\left(de/(bc);q \right)_{n}}{\left(e;q\right)_{n}}\left(\frac{bc}{d}\right)^{n}{{}_{3}\phi_{2} }\left({q^{-n},d/b,d/c\atop d,de/(bc)};q,q\right), , {{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^{-n},b,c\atop d,e};q,q\right)=\frac{\left(e/c;q\right )_{n}}{\left(e;q\right)_{n}}c^{n}{{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^{-n},c,d/b\atop d,cq ^{1-n}/e};q,\frac{bq}{e}\right), , {{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^{-n},b,c\atop d,e};q,\frac{deq^{n}}{bc}\right)=\frac{ \left(e/c;q\right)_{n}}{\left(e;q\right)_{n}}{{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({q^{-n},c,d /b\atop d,cq^{1-n}/e};q,q\right).

With a=q^{-n} and n a nonnegative integer, {{}_{3}\phi_{2}}\left({a,b,c\atop aq/b,aq/c};q,\frac{aqz}{bc}\right)=\frac{ \left(az;q\right)_{\infty}}{\left(z;q\right)_{\infty}}\*{{}_{5}\phi_{4}}\left( {a^{\frac{1}{2}},-a^{\frac{1}{2}},(aq)^{\frac{1}{2}},-(aq)^{\frac{1}{2}},aq/( bc)\atop aq/b,aq/c,az,q/z};q,q\right).

\left({{}_{4}\phi_{3}}\left({a,b,abz,ab/z\atop abq^{\frac{1}{2}},-abq^{\frac{1 }{2}},-ab};q,q\right)\right)^{2}={{}_{5}\phi_{4}}\left({a^{2},b^{2},ab,abz,ab/ z\atop abq^{\frac{1}{2}},-abq^{\frac{1}{2}},-ab,a^{2}b^{2}};q,q\right), provided that the series expansions of both \phi ’s terminate.
Of (LABEL:eq:QH.12.1)–(LABEL:eq:QH.12.3)only (LABEL:eq:QH.12.1) has a natural generalization: the following sum reduces to (LABEL:eq:QH.12.1) when n=2.

A sequence of pairs of rational functions of several variables (\alpha_{n},\beta_{n}) , n=0,1,2,\dots , is called a Bailey pair provided that for each n\geqq 0 \beta_{n}=\sum_{j=0}^{n}\frac{\alpha_{j}}{\left(q;q\right)_{n-j}\left(aq;q \right)_{n+j}}.
If (\alpha_{n},\beta_{n}) is a Bailey pair, then \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}q^{n^{2}}a^{n}\beta_{n}=\frac{1}{\left(aq;q\right)_{\infty} }\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}q^{n^{2}}a^{n}\alpha_{n}.

If (\alpha_{n},\beta_{n}) is a Bailey pair, then so is (\alpha_{n}^{\prime},\beta_{n}^{\prime}) , where \left(\frac{aq}{\rho_{1}},\frac{aq}{\rho_{2}};q\right)_{n}\alpha_{n}^{\prime}= \left(\rho_{1},\rho_{2};q\right)_{n}\left(\frac{aq}{\rho_{1}\rho_{2}}\right)^{ n}\alpha_{n}, \left(\frac{aq}{\rho_{1}},\frac{aq}{\rho_{2}};q\right)_{n}\beta_{n}^{\prime}= \sum_{j=0}^{n}\left(\rho_{1},\rho_{2};q\right)_{j}\left(\frac{aq}{\rho_{1}\rho _{2}};q\right)_{n-j}\left(\frac{aq}{\rho_{1}\rho_{2}}\right)^{j}\frac{\beta_{j }}{\left(q;q\right)_{n-j}}
When (LABEL:eq:QH.13.5) is iterated the resulting infinite sequence of Bailey pairs is called a Bailey Chain.

The Bailey pair that implies the Rogers–Ramanujan identities §LABEL:sec:QH.2.(vi) is: \alpha_{n}=\frac{\left(a;q\right)_{n}(1-aq^{2n})(-1)^{n}q^{n(3n-1)/2}a^{n}}{ \left(q;q\right)_{n}(1-a)}, \beta_{n}=\frac{1}{\left(q;q\right)_{n}}.
The Bailey pair and Bailey chain concepts have been extended considerably.
In this section, for the function \Gamma_{q} see §LABEL:sec:GA.GF.QG.
( ) conjectured extensions of the foregoing integrals that are closely related to ( ) .
These conjectures are proved independently in ( ) and ( ) .

\frac{\left(q;q\right)_{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}}{\left(q;q\right)_{a_{1}} \left(q;q\right)_{a_{2}}\cdots\left(q;q\right)_{a_{n}}}=\mbox{ coeff. of }x_{1 }^{0}x_{2}^{0}\cdots x_{n}^{0}\mbox{ in }\prod_{1\leq j<k\leq n}\left(\frac{x_ {j}}{x_{k}};q\right)_{a_{j}}\left(\frac{qx_{k}}{x_{j}};q\right)_{a_{k}}.
In the following, G(q) and H(q) denote the left-hand sides of(LABEL:eq:QH.2.49) and (LABEL:eq:QH.2.50), respectively.

_{\infty}\left(-z^{-1}q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty} }{\left(z^{-1}q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(-q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(z ^{-1}q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}=\frac{1}{\left(-q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}\mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(-z^{-1}q ;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}{\left(z^{-1}q;q\right )_{\infty}}=\frac{H(q)}{\left(-q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}, \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{q^{n(n+1)}}{\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{n}\left(-q;q^{2 }\right)_{n+1}}=\mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right) _{\infty}\left(-z^{-1}q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty} }{\left(z^{-1};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(-q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(z^{-1} q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}=\frac{1}{\left(-q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}\mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(-z^{-1}q;q^{2} \right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}{\left(z^{-1};q\right)_{ \infty}}=\frac{G(q)}{\left(-q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}, \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{q^{n^{2}}}{\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{n}\left(q;q^{2} \right)_{n}}=\mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right)_{ \infty}\left(-z^{-1}q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}{ \left(-z^{-1};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(z^{-1};q ^{2}\right)_{\infty}}=\frac{1}{\left(q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}\mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(-z^{-1}q;q^{2} \right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}{\left(z^{-2};q^{4}\right)_{ \infty}}=\frac{G(q^{4})}{\left(q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}, \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{q^{n^{2}+2n}}{\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{n}\left(q;q^{ 2}\right)_{n+1}}=\mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right )_{\infty}\left(-z^{-1}q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty }}{\left(-q^{2}z^{-1};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left( z^{-1}q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}=\frac{1}{\left(q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}} \mbox{ coeff. of }z^{0}\mbox{ in }\frac{\left(-zq;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(- z^{-1}q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}\left(q^{2};q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}{\left(q^{4}z^{ -2};q^{4}\right)_{\infty}}=\frac{H(q^{4})}{\left(q;q^{2}\right)_{\infty}}.
( ) includes extensive conjectures on generalizations of (LABEL:eq:QH.15.1) to root systems.
These conjectures were proved in ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) ; see also ( ) .
For additional results of the type (LABEL:eq:QH.15.5)–(LABEL:eq:QH.15.8) see ( , Chapter 4) .
For higher-dimensional basic hypergometric functions, see ( ) and ( ) .
Many special cases of q -series arise in the theory of partitions, a topic treated in §§LABEL:sec:NT.FNS.PTa and LABEL:sec:CM.RNP.
In Lie algebras ( ) and ( ) laid foundations for extensive interaction with q -series.
These and other applications are described in the surveys ( ) .
More recent applications are given in ( , Chapter 8) and ( , Chapters 1 and 2) .
In exactly solved models in statistical mechanics ( ( ) ) the methods and identities of §LABEL:sec:QH.13 play a substantial role.
Quantum groups also apply q -series extensively.
Quantum groups are really not groups at all but certain Hopf algebras.
They were given this name because they play a role in quantum physics analogous to the role of Lie groups and special functions in classical mechanics.
A substantial literature on q -deformed quantum-mechanical Schrödinger equations has developed recently.
It involves q -generalizations of exponentials and Laguerre polynomials, and has been applied to the problems of the harmonic oscillator and Coulomb potentials.
See ( ) , where many earlier references are cited.
For computation of the q -exponential function see ( ) .
The two main methods for computing basic hypergeometric functions are: (1) numerical summation of the defining series given in §§LABEL:sec:QH.4(i)and LABEL:sec:QH.4(ii);(2) modular transformations.
Method (1) is applicable within the circles of convergence of the defining series, although it is often cumbersome owing to slowness of convergence and/or severe cancellation.
Method (2) is very powerful when applicable ( ( , Chapter 5) ); however, it is applicable only rarely.
( ) uses Method (2) in connection with the Rogers–Ramanujan identities.
Method (1) can sometimes be improved by application of convergence accelerationprocedures; see §LABEL:sec:NM.AOC.
( ) applies such methods in several q -series problems; see ( ) .
In this section we provide links to the research literature describing the implementation of algorithms in software for the evaluation of functions described in this chapter.
Citations in the bulleted list refer to papers for which research software has been made available and can be downloaded via the Web.
